title: IB Physics - Measurements & Uncertainties
subject: physics
description: Quiz covering SI units, uncertainties, significant figures, and error propagation for IB Physics
author: OpenNotes

questions.question: Which of the following is a fundamental SI base unit?
questions.explanation: The ampere is one of the 7 SI base units. The newton, joule, and pascal are all derived units.

questions.question: A student measures the length of a rod as $5.0 \pm 0.1$ cm and the width as $2.0 \pm 0.1$ cm. The percentage uncertainty in the area is:
questions.explanation: Percentage uncertainties: length $= \frac{0.1}{5.0} \times 100 = 2\%$, width $= \frac{0.1}{2.0} \times 100 = 5\%$. For multiplication, add percentages: $2\% + 5\% = 7\%$

questions.question: The order of magnitude of the mass of a proton ($1.67 \times 10^{-27}$ kg) is:
questions.explanation: $1.67 \times 10^{-27}$ is closer to $10^{-27}$ than $10^{-26}$, so the order of magnitude is $10^{-27}$ kg

questions.question: How many significant figures are in the measurement $0.00340$ m?
questions.explanation: Leading zeros are not significant. The digits 3, 4, and the trailing 0 are significant. Answer: 3

questions.question: If $T = 2\pi\sqrt{\frac{l}{g}}$, the percentage uncertainty in $T$ when $l$ has 4% uncertainty is:
A systematic error in an experiment causes measurements to be:
options: Randomly scattered around the true value
questions.explanation: Systematic errors cause all measurements to be shifted in one direction (too high or too low). Random errors cause scatter.

questions.question: Express the unit of force (newton) in terms of SI base units:
A set of measurements has high precision but low accuracy. This means:
options: Values are close together but far from the true value
Values are spread out but centered on the true value
Values are both close together and near the true value
Values are spread out and far from the true value
questions.explanation: Precision = reproducibility (close together). Accuracy = closeness to true value. High precision + low accuracy = clustered but off-target.
